results.title: You don't know why you came here
results.creator_credit: Martin Williams Films, Millie Williams and Dick Marks
results.brief_description: Trisha returns home to Queensland after years abroad. She travels through the state while a musical soundtrack provides a background to the scenery. No spoken commentary. Music by Terry Hannigan.

results.title: You don't have to be mad
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Peter Johnson and Greg Reading
results.brief_description: Discusses what sort of people a psychologist can help, and how they can help them, especially in the employment field. Uses light-hearted as well as serious examples. Cast includes Bruce Spence, Graeme Blundell. Assistant producer, Rosemary Gow; director, script, Greg Reading; photographers, John Hosking, Ross King; editor, Tom Foley; sound, Lloyd Carrick, Rod Simmons; commentator, Paul Ricketts.

results.title: You can go a long way!
results.creator_credit: San Life Assurance Co of Canada and Donald Wilder
results.brief_description: Designed to allow students to explore, in their own way, the reasons why it is wise to finish school, and get as much training and education as possible before looking for a job. Tells in a light way what parents and teachers sometimes knock themselves out trying to prove: that competition is keen in the bread-and -butter world and that the best jobs go to the candidate with the best qualifications.

results.title: You can do it!
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Michael E. Bernard. This video is designed to aid students (and others) in developing the skills and essential attitudes necessary for success in school and happiness in life. The video addresses issues such as goal setting, time management, attitudes, self-confidence, self-motivation, exam anxiety and relationships.

results.title: You Can Do It Too!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Diane O'Connor
results.brief_description: A character called “x”, who is neither male nor female, points out all the opportunities available to people when gender is made irrelevant. Shows how role stereotyping begins at birth and carries through into school and work. Shows men and women working and finding fulfilment in non-traditional areas. The band playing towards the end of the film features the now ABC political journalist, Fran Kelly, in an unfamiliar guise.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Diane O’Connor

results.title: You can do it
results.brief_description: Presented by and starring Shari Lewis, the well-loved ventriloquist, storyteller and singing personality in a magical, fun-filled hour of easy magic, simple puppets, dopey dares and silly stunts. Join Shari and the beloved Lamb Chop and Hush Puppy as they celebrate Charley Horse’s birthday party with music and singing, rope tricks, paper tricks, card tricks, a demonstration on ventriloquism and making puppets from paper and fruit.

results.title: You can do anything
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler
results.brief_description: The Kirinara Hostel in N.S.W. offers an educational program specifically designed for young Aboriginal and Islander people. The video focuses on students at the hostel and includes interviews with ex-students who have pursued careers in a diverse range of fields including law, teaching, football and dance. The graduates stress the importance of individuals setting realistic goals for themselves as well as the need for Aboriginal education support schemes to assist young Aboriginal people to achieve their full educational potential.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler
